Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Natural History Collections: Curation, Digitization, Integration, and On-Line Access of Two Exceptional Invertebrate Fossil Research Collections
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks funding to salvage two unique collections and permanently house them in the Invertebrate Paleontology Division of the Florida Museum of Natural History (FLMNH). These collections were no longer afforded adequate storage at their home institutions. The larger of the two is an exceptional, nationally unique inventory of fossil micro-mollusks. The second collection is composed of critical reference specimens used originally to develop a powerful technique for numerical age dating of fossils (the amino acid racemization method). Both collections will be used extensively in research, education, and training of a new generation of scientists. Diverse audiences will benefit directly from two new exhibits developed using these collections. Additionally, two identification guides will be produced and 1,500 specimen images will be made available through on-line portals and the FLMNH's image galleries. The project will involve hands-on training of undergraduate interns, result in newsletter articles and talks to local groups, and contribute important specimens to public exhibits at the FLMNH and elsewhere.

This project seeks to curate, digitize, and publish data from two unique invertebrate fossil collections recently acquired by the Florida Museum of Natural History (FLMNH). The first collection (~30,000 lots) was assembled by Lyle Campbell (University of South Carolina, Upstate) during 40 years of fieldwork in Cenozoic deposits of Virginia, the Carolinas, and Georgia. The collection is a nationally unique scientific resource representing a taxonomically diverse bio-inventory of micro-mollusks. The second collection (~3,000 lots) was assembled by John Wehmiller (University of Delaware) over the past 35 years during the development of amino acid racemization (AAR) dating methods. Both collections will be integrated into the Specify 6.6, a relational database that unifies all FLMNH paleontological and neontological specimen collections. The project will make two significant collections readily available to the global research community, thus providing a stimulus for research. The collection of numerous, rare, and undescribed species of micro-mollusks, severely underrepresented in FLMNH's holdings, will be of broad value to malacologists and paleontologists. This collection is particularly valuable for filling gaps in the fossil record (e.g., tropical Paleogene) and are uniquely suitable for quantitative macro-ecological studies (e.g., ecological niche modeling). The second collection contains key reference materials for geochronological studies needed to validate past research findings and assist Quaternary geochronologists with the development of new dating strategies. Upon completion, the project will result in novel high-quality data on spatial and temporal distribution of Cenozoic invertebrates. These records will be fully integrated into existing data networks (e.g., iDigBio, GBIF, PBDB, and Earth Cube).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funds were expended to complete a three-year project to curate, computer-catalog (digitize), and incorporate, two exceptional but endangered research collections into the holdings of the Division of Invertebrate Paleontology at the Florida Museum of Natural History (FM), University of Florida (UF). All information and some digital images from these significant collections were then added to our online database (http://specifyportal.flmnh.ufl.edu/ip/) to serve all interested parties (researchers, educators, and the public) worldwide. Furthermore, data from the two collections [University of South Carolina Upstate (USCU) and University of Delaware (UD)] is provided to the Neogene Atlas of Ancient Life - Southeastern United States (http://www.neogeneatlas.net/) to help populate their popular website which provide ways to explore diversity, geographic distribution, evolution, and paleoecology of fossils that the public might encounter.

The largest collection curated was that of the USCU that consists mostly of fossil marine invertebrates (snails, clams, sand dollars, etc.) from Delaware, Virginia, North and South Carolina, and Georgia which lived in the area during the past 35 million years.  The collection (nearly 30,000 lots) was amassed during 40 years of fieldwork by Dr. Lyle Campbell and family (USCU) and Dr. Joseph Carter (University of North Carolina Chapel Hill) and were instrumental in helping define stratigraphy and ages of rock units in these states.  Furthermore, they contain some of the best documented collections from the SE USA from sites no longer accessible due to rampant land development. The smaller collection (nearly 3,000 lots) was amassed during the past 35 years by Dr. John Wehmiller at the University of Delaware (UD) to determine the age of rocks along the Atlantic Coastal Plain.  Most of the collection of mollusks (snails and clams) was made for the purpose of development and application of amino acid racemization (AAR) dating methods.  Thus far these collections have been the source of over 70 scientific publications and are expected to remain of high interest to the scientific community. Now curated, these materials will be used to help estimate past regional and global climate change through geochemistry of certain fossils and help determine sea level flucuations and paleoshorelines through time, to contribute to ecological niche modeling of snails and clams over the last 20 million years, and used to produce more accurate geological maps.  

Funding provided for this curation helped train our undergraduate and graduate students, post-doctoral students, non-student personnel, and volunteers.  Each learned about invertebrate scientific names (taxonomy), hard-part anatomy, geography, and geology.  Furthermore instruction of modern curatorial techniques, specimen conservation, digital photography, and use of computer software (e.g., Specify, Google Earth Professional, Excel) was provided. Additionally, individuals were exposed to in-house and visiting researchers (both domestic and foreign) and their research endeavours.

Through evaluating the USCU Collection and other incoming materials (donations and field collections) made during the grant period, excess specimens and those lacking data, were supplied to local and regional elementary and middle schools, the FM Exhibits and Education Department (e.g., give-aways for Earth Day and National Fossil Day events and for Fossil Hall Discovery Carts), state wide-fossil and shell clubs (e.g., dig pits), the National Park Service (Junior Paleontologist Educational Kits), and the public to help teach about the diversity of life on Earth, evolution, and how fossils and geology are extremely important and an everday part of their lives (e.g., fossil-rich limestones and shell beds are used in Florida roads and in construction materials like concrete).
